page.title: 06THE HERMITAGE EDINBURGH
page.content: A hermit once lived in the Hermitage and that is how it got its' name. It was a wild forest but now is a{wooded {park.}He probably lived on wild berries, boar and squirrel. In 1772 the Hermitage was sold to Sir Charles Gordon of Cluny. By 1785 he had finished building the{mansion {house}we can see today. He built a doo'cot up on the hills where pigeons were kept for eating. The doo'cot faced south so that the north winds couldn't blow in. There is also an Ice House which faced north where he kept salted meat. The ice was brought from the river in winter and taken along many winding passages so that the sun could not melt it. It was then wrapped in straw. People believed that there was a tunnel from the Ice House to the servants' quarters in the house.
